title: Sydney property in Surry Hills goes on the market for $2m
title_page: Sydney property in Surry Hills goes on the market for $2m | Daily Mail Online
text:
A rundown home with crumbling walls and duct tape keeping the floors together has gone on the market for nearly $2million.
The dilapidated property in Sydney's inner east has been priced at $1,850,000 - just days after it was revealed that one in ten properties in New South Wales are bought by foreign investors.
The semi on Reservoir Street in trendy Surry Hills is being labelled by agents as one for 'true romantics' with natural light and an 'Old World sense of space'.

The property can hardly be seen as an accessible entry into one of Sydney's most popular suburbs either.
The median price for four bedroom homes in Surry Hills is only $300,000 higher than the Reservoir Street property, according to Domain.
Average house prices in Surry Hills have more than doubled in the space of five years.

The median price for a Surry Hills property in 2012 was $985,000.
Sydney homes have proved popular with foreign investors recently, with about 2,995 properties being snapped up by foreigners within a three month period last year.
After the foreign investment figures were released, NSW Treasurer Dominic Perrottet said he would increase surcharges for foreigners in the June Budget in an effort to help Australian home buyers.
'The great Australian dream is to own your own home,' Mr Perrottet said.
'While foreign investment brings an important flow of capital into NSW, my priority is to ensure Australians have that opportunity first.'
